definitions: stay away from a place or event that one is expected to attend
deliberately choose to remove oneself from a particular place or situation
examples: He decided to absent himself from the meeting
Students who absent themselves frequently may fail the course
She absented herself from the party without explanation
The CEO rarely absents himself from board meetings

definitions: formally declare someone free from guilt, blame, or responsibility for wrongdoing
officially release someone from a duty, obligation, or promise they had made
examples: The priest absolved him of his sins after confession
The court absolved her of all criminal charges
The contract absolves the company from any liability
His apology doesn't absolve him from his responsibilities

definitions: take in or soak up liquid or other substance through a surface or pores
take in and understand information, knowledge, or ideas fully and completely
take up all of someone's attention or interest so they think of nothing else
take in and incorporate something as part of a larger whole or system
examples: The sponge absorbed all the water from the counter
Plants absorb nutrients through their roots
She quickly absorbed the complex mathematical concepts
Children absorb languages more easily than adults
The fascinating book completely absorbed her attention
He was so absorbed in his work he forgot to eat
The larger company absorbed three smaller competitors last year
The city gradually absorbed the surrounding villages

definitions: deliberately choose not to do or have something that you want or enjoy
restrain oneself from consuming food, drink, or other substances for health or moral reasons
formally decline to vote either for or against a proposal or motion
examples: She abstained from commenting on the controversial issue
The doctor advised him to abstain from strenuous exercise
Many people abstain from alcohol during January
He abstains from meat for religious reasons
Three members voted yes, two voted no, and one abstained
Several countries abstained from the UN resolution vote

definitions: extract or summarize the essential meaning or most important aspects from something complex
remove or separate something from its physical or concrete context or location
consider something as a theoretical concept apart from concrete realities or specific instances
examples: She abstracted the key findings from the lengthy research paper
The artist abstracted the main elements from the landscape
The data was abstracted from various medical records
Scientists abstracted DNA from the blood samples
It's difficult to abstract these principles from their cultural context
Philosophers often abstract universal truths from particular experiences

definitions: treat a person or animal with cruelty or violence, especially regularly or repeatedly
use something in a way that is wrong, harmful, or not intended by its makers
speak to someone in an insulting, offensive, or unnecessarily critical way
examples: The investigation revealed that staff had abused elderly residents
Children who are abused often struggle with trust issues
Some athletes abuse performance-enhancing drugs to gain advantage
Don't abuse your privileges or they will be taken away
The angry customer abused the staff with offensive language
Opposition politicians abused the minister during the debate

definitions: agree to a demand, request, or treaty, often reluctantly or after consideration
formally assume an office, throne, or position of power and responsibility
examples: The government finally acceded to the protesters' demands
After long negotiations, both parties acceded to the terms
Queen Elizabeth II acceded to the throne in 1952
The vice president acceded to the presidency after resignation

definitions: begin to move more quickly or increase the speed of movement or travel
cause a process, development, or progress to happen more quickly than normal
cause a vehicle or object to increase its speed or rate of movement
examples: The car accelerated smoothly from zero to sixty
Her heartbeat accelerated when she saw the results
Climate change appears to be accelerating faster than predicted
The new policy will accelerate economic growth
He accelerated the car to overtake the truck
The enzyme accelerates the chemical reaction significantly

definitions: pronounce a word or syllable with particular stress or distinctive pronunciation
emphasize or draw special attention to a particular feature or quality
examples: In Spanish, you must accent the second syllable correctly
She accented her words carefully for the audience
The designer accented the room with bold colored pillows
His speech accented the need for immediate action

definitions: make a feature, quality, or characteristic more noticeable or prominent than usual
give special importance or prominence to something in speaking, writing, or design
examples: The tight dress accentuated her slim figure
Bright lighting accentuates the architectural details
The report accentuates the positive aspects of the proposal
His comments only accentuated the existing tensions

definitions: consent to receive or undertake something offered or given by another person
give an affirmative answer to an offer, invitation, or proposal; agree to terms
believe or come to recognize an opinion, explanation, or fact as valid or correct
tolerate or submit to something unpleasant or undesired but unavoidable
examples: She accepted the award with grace and humility
The university accepted her into the graduate program
He accepted the job offer without hesitation
They accepted our invitation to the wedding
Scientists now accept the theory of evolution
The court accepted his explanation of events
You need to accept that some things cannot be changed
She gradually accepted her father's death

definitions: formally record the addition of a new item to a library or museum collection
formally become a party to a treaty or agreement between states
examples: The museum accessioned fifty new paintings this year
Libraries must properly accession all donated materials
Several countries are expected to accession the treaty
The state accessioned to the international agreement

definitions: praise someone or something enthusiastically and publicly, especially in media or reviews
elect or declare someone to a position by enthusiastic approval rather than formal vote
examples: Critics acclaimed her performance as the best of the year
The novel was widely acclaimed for its innovative style
The delegates acclaimed him as their new leader
She was acclaimed president by unanimous consent

definitions: provide lodging, room, or space for someone to stay or for something to fit
provide enough space or room for a particular number of people or things
adjust or modify something to suit particular needs, requirements, or circumstances
examples: The hotel can accommodate up to 200 guests
We accommodated the visiting team in nearby dormitories
The new stadium accommodates fifty thousand spectators
This parking lot accommodates only compact cars
The school accommodates students with special learning needs
We can accommodate your request for a later deadline

definitions: go somewhere with someone as a companion, escort, or provider of protection
exist, occur, or be present at the same time as something else
play a musical instrument, especially piano, while someone else sings or plays the melody
examples: She accompanied her elderly mother to the doctor
Security guards accompanied the diplomat everywhere
Fever often accompanies the flu
Thunder usually accompanies lightning during storms
He accompanied the singer on the piano
She accompanied herself on the guitar

definitions: successfully complete a task, project, or objective that requires effort or skill
succeed in doing or achieving something planned or attempted despite difficulties
examples: She accomplished all her goals before turning thirty
The team accomplished the project ahead of schedule
He accomplished what many thought was impossible
They accomplished their mission despite numerous setbacks

definitions: give or grant someone power, status, or recognition in a formal or official way
be in agreement, harmony, or consistent with something else in opinion or action
examples: The university accorded her an honorary degree
He was accorded full diplomatic privileges
His actions don't accord with his stated principles
The results accord perfectly with our predictions

definitions: give a satisfactory explanation or justification for one's actions, decisions, or whereabouts
regard or consider someone or something in a specified way or as having particular characteristics
examples: She couldn't account for the missing money
How do you account for his strange behavior?
He is accounted one of the best surgeons
This discovery was accounted a major breakthrough

definitions: accumulate or receive payments or benefits gradually over a period of time
arise or come about as a natural growth, increase, or advantage from something
examples: Interest accrues daily on this savings account
She accrued substantial vacation time over the years
Significant benefits accrue from regular exercise
Power accrues to those who control information

definitions: gather together or acquire an increasing number or quantity of something over time
gradually increase in number, quantity, or degree through continuous additions
examples: She accumulated a fortune through wise investments
Dust accumulated on the unused furniture
Evidence accumulated that supported the new theory
Snow accumulated rapidly during the blizzard

definitions: formally charge someone with a crime, offense, or wrongdoing in a legal context
claim that someone has done something wrong, illegal, or morally questionable
examples: The prosecutor accused him of embezzlement
She was falsely accused of stealing money
He accused his colleague of lying about the incident
They accused the company of environmental violations

definitions: perform exceptionally well on a test, exam, or challenging task
defeat an opponent easily or decisively in a competition or game
examples: She aced all her final exams this semester
He aced the job interview and got hired immediately
The champion aced his opponent in straight sets
Our team completely aced the competition

definitions: experience a continuous dull pain in a part of the body
feel intense longing, yearning, or emotional pain for someone or something
examples: My back aches from sitting too long
Her joints ached in the cold weather
His heart ached for his distant homeland
She ached to see her children again

definitions: successfully bring about or accomplish a desired objective, goal, or result through effort
reach or attain a desired level of success, performance, or recognition
examples: She achieved her dream of becoming a doctor
The company achieved record profits this year
He achieved fame through his innovative designs
Few athletes achieve such a high level of excellence

definitions: accept or admit the existence, truth, or validity of something, often reluctantly
express gratitude or appreciation for something done or given by another person
confirm that one has received something such as a letter, email, or payment
examples: She finally acknowledged her mistakes
The government acknowledged the need for reform
He acknowledged their help in his speech
The author acknowledged her editor's contributions
Please acknowledge receipt of this message
The bank acknowledged the payment immediately

definitions: make someone aware of or familiar with something through experience or information
make someone known to another person through formal or informal introduction
examples: The tour will acquaint you with campus facilities
She acquainted herself with the new software
Let me acquaint you with our new manager
They were acquainted at a conference last year

definitions: accept something reluctantly but without protest or active resistance
passively comply with or submit to something without enthusiasm or approval
examples: She acquiesced to their demands to avoid conflict
The board finally acquiesced in the merger proposal
He acquiesced when faced with overwhelming opposition
They reluctantly acquiesced to the new regulations

definitions: buy, obtain, or come to possess something, especially something valuable or desirable
learn or develop a skill, habit, or quality through effort or experience over time
buy or take control of another company or business through purchase or merger
examples: The museum acquired several rare paintings
She acquired property in three different states
Children acquire language naturally through interaction
He acquired a taste for classical music
The corporation acquired its main competitor last year
They plan to acquire smaller tech startups

definitions: formally declare someone not guilty of a criminal charge in a court of law
conduct oneself or perform in a specified way, especially under difficult circumstances
examples: The jury acquitted her of all charges
He was acquitted due to lack of evidence
She acquitted herself admirably during the crisis
The team acquitted themselves well in the tournament

definitions: do something or take steps to achieve a purpose or deal with a situation
behave in a particular way or manner, especially one that is not genuine
perform a role in a play, film, or television production as an actor
fulfill the function or serve the purpose of something else temporarily or permanently
examples: We must act quickly to prevent disaster
The government acted to reduce unemployment
Stop acting like a child
He's just acting tough to impress others
She acts in local theater productions
He acted the part of Hamlet brilliantly
This lever acts as a brake
She acted as interpreter during the meeting

definitions: begin legal proceedings against someone in a court of law
put a plan, process, or decision into operation or effect
examples: The company decided to action the complaint immediately
The lawyer will action the case next week
Management will action these recommendations by month end
We need to action this proposal without delay

definitions: make something active or operative by supplying power or initiating a process
cause a device, system, or process to start functioning or operating
make a substance radioactive by bombardment with neutrons or other particles
examples: Press this button to activate the alarm
You need to activate your credit card before use
The sensor activates the automatic doors
Heat activates the chemical reaction
Scientists activated the sample in the nuclear reactor
The neutron bombardment activated the metal

definitions: make something suitable for a new use, purpose, or situation by modifying it
become adjusted to new conditions, environment, or circumstances through change
alter a text, musical composition, or dramatic work for presentation in another medium
examples: They adapted the tool for underwater use
The company adapted its products for foreign markets
Plants adapt to their environment over generations
She quickly adapted to life in the city
He adapted the novel for television
The play was adapted from a short story

definitions: join something to something else to increase the size, number, amount, or scope
put two or more numbers or amounts together to calculate their total sum
say something more as a further comment or afterthought to what was said
examples: Add sugar to taste
She added three new chapters to her book
If you add five and seven, you get twelve
Add all the expenses to find the total
He added that the meeting was mandatory
I should add that parking is free

definitions: cause someone to become physically or psychologically dependent on a substance or activity
cause someone to become devoted to or obsessed with an interest or activity
examples: The powerful painkillers addicted him within months
These drugs can addict users after just one use
The game's design deliberately addicts players
She's completely addicted to social media

definitions: stick fast or firmly to a surface or substance through physical attachment
closely follow, observe, or maintain loyalty to a rule, belief, or principle
examples: The tape won't adhere to wet surfaces
Make sure the label adheres properly
All employees must adhere to safety regulations
She adheres strictly to her religious beliefs

definitions: be next to and joined with another building, room, or piece of land
attach, append, or add something as a joining or connected part
examples: Their property adjoins the national park
The dining room adjoins the kitchen
They plan to adjoin a new wing to the hospital
The architect adjoined two buildings with a corridor

definitions: break off a meeting, legal proceeding, or game with intention to resume later
put off or postpone a meeting, trial, or decision to a later time
examples: The judge adjourned the court until tomorrow
Parliament adjourned for the summer recess
They adjourned the hearing pending new evidence
The committee adjourned the vote until next week

definitions: make a formal judgment or decision about a problem, dispute, or contested matter
act as a judge in a competition, dispute, or formal proceeding
examples: The court will adjudicate the dispute next month
The panel adjudicated all claims fairly
She was asked to adjudicate the art competition
He adjudicated between the two parties

definitions: alter or move something slightly to achieve a better fit, appearance, or result
adapt or become accustomed to a new situation, environment, or set of conditions
examples: She adjusted the mirror to see better
You can adjust the temperature with this dial
It took time to adjust to the new schedule
He's still adjusting to life after retirement

definitions: manage and be responsible for the running of a business, organization, or system
give or apply medicine, drugs, or remedies to someone for treatment
deliver or apply something formally or officially, such as an oath or punishment
examples: She administers three different departments
The board administers the company's pension fund
The nurse administered pain medication every four hours
Doctors administered emergency treatment at the scene
The judge administered the oath to witnesses
The principal administered punishment for cheating

definitions: regard someone or something with respect, approval, or warm appreciation for qualities
look at something with pleasure and appreciation for its beauty or excellence
examples: She admired his courage and determination
I really admire people who speak multiple languages
They stopped to admire the mountain view
Everyone admired her beautiful wedding dress

definitions: confess to be true or to be the case, typically with reluctance or shame
allow someone to enter a place, building, or institution after meeting requirements
accept someone into a hospital for medical treatment or into an organization
examples: He finally admitted his mistake
She admitted that she had lied
Security admitted only those with valid tickets
This pass admits two people
The hospital admitted him for emergency surgery
The university admits five thousand students annually

definitions: legally take another person's child into one's family and raise as one's own
choose to take up, follow, or use a new method, practice, or attitude
formally approve or accept a proposal, policy, or report by voting
examples: They adopted two children from overseas
She was adopted as a baby
The company adopted new safety procedures
He adopted a healthier lifestyle after his diagnosis
Parliament adopted the resolution unanimously
The committee adopted the new guidelines

definitions: love and respect someone or something deeply and feel great affection for them
worship and honor a deity with religious devotion and reverence
examples: She absolutely adores her grandchildren
He adores everything about Italian culture
The faithful adore God through prayer and song
Ancient peoples adored many different deities

definitions: make something more beautiful or attractive by adding decorative items or features
be a decoration or enhancement that adds beauty to something or someone
examples: She adorned the room with fresh flowers
They adorned themselves with jewelry for the celebration
Beautiful paintings adorned every wall
Colorful banners adorned the festival streets

definitions: move forward in a purposeful way, especially in position or time
make progress or help something make progress in development or improvement
give or lend money before it is due or pay before receiving goods
put forward an idea, theory, or suggestion for consideration by others
examples: The troops advanced toward the enemy position
Please advance to the next chapter
Technology continues to advance rapidly
The research advanced our understanding significantly
The company advanced him a month's salary
Can you advance me twenty dollars until tomorrow?
She advanced a new theory about climate change
He advanced several proposals at the meeting

definitions: put someone in a favorable or superior position compared to others
exploit or make unfair use of someone for one's own benefit
examples: The new rules advantage larger companies
This policy advantages wealthy students
He tried to advantage himself at others' expense
Don't let them advantage themselves from your kindness

definitions: engage in exciting, unusual, or daring experiences involving unknown risks
dare to do something risky or venture somewhere dangerous or unknown
examples: They adventured through the Amazon rainforest
She loves to adventure in remote places
Few would adventure into those dangerous waters
He adventured his entire fortune on the venture

definitions: make a reference or mention something briefly in speaking or writing
turn one's attention or consideration to something particular
examples: The speaker adverted to recent political events
She adverted briefly to her childhood
Let me advert to the main issue
We must advert our attention to this problem
